    { id: "3916", front: "What is the scientific term for the study of extreme limits of material strength and behavior (e.g., at high pressures or temperatures)?", back: "Rheology (or Extreme Materials Science)", subject: "Materials Science" },
    { id: "3917", front: "What is the concept that the fundamental physical constants of the universe are 'fine-tuned' for life to exist?", back: "Anthropic Principle", subject: "Cosmology" },
    { id: "3918", front: "What is the difference between an exothermic and an endothermic reaction?", back: "Exothermic releases energy (heat); Endothermic absorbs energy (heat)", subject: "Chemistry" },
    { id: "3919", front: "What statistical measure describes the spread of data points around the mean?", back: "Standard Deviation", subject: "Mathematics/Statistics" },
    { id: "3920", front: "What is the name of the hypothetical state of matter where particles are compressed to the point that their wave functions overlap (e.g., inside a neutron star)?", back: "Degenerate Matter (or Quantum Degeneracy)", subject: "Quantum Physics" },
    { id: "3921", front: "What is the term for a theoretical object that exists in a higher-dimensional space and only appears as a 3D bubble or surface in our reality?", back: "Brane (from String Theory)", subject: "Theoretical Physics" },
    { id: "3922", front: "What is the concept that a system, such as a black hole, is characterized only by its mass, charge, and angular momentum?", back: "No-Hair Theorem", subject: "Theoretical Physics" },
    { id: "3923", front: "What is the term for the lowest possible energy state of a system (even at absolute zero) due to the Uncertainty Principle?", back: "Zero-Point Energy", subject: "Quantum Physics" },
    { id: "3924", front: "What area of mathematics is primarily concerned with the study of shapes and the properties of spaces, often independent of distance?", back: "Topology", subject: "Mathematics" },
    { id: "3925", front: "What is the term for the study of the structure and evolution of the universe?", back: "Cosmology", subject: "Astronomy" },
    { id: "3926", front: "What scientific philosophy states that the simplest explanation is usually the best one?", back: "Occam's Razor (Principle of Parsimony)", subject: "Philosophy of Science" },
    { id: "3927", front: "What is the engineering term for the application of forces to change the speed or direction of a body (often in aerospace)?", back: "Thrust", subject: "Aerospace Engineering" },
    { id: "3928", front: "What is the term for a material that is not magnetized, but can be attracted to a magnet?", back: "Ferromagnetic", subject: "Physics" },
    { id: "3929", front: "What is the term for the difference between the actual mass of a nucleus and the sum of the masses of its constituent nucleons?", back: "Mass Defect", subject: "Nuclear Physics" },
    { id: "3930", front: "What is the term for the resistance experienced by an object moving through a fluid or gas?", back: "Drag (or Fluid Resistance)", subject: "Physics" },
    { id: "3931", front: "What term is used to describe a system that is in thermal, mechanical, and chemical equilibrium?", back: "Thermodynamic Equilibrium", subject: "Thermodynamics" },
    { id: "3932", front: "What is the scientific term for the study of sound and sound waves?", back: "Acoustics", subject: "Physics" },
    { id: "3933", front: "What is the term for the energy required to separate the nucleons (protons and neutrons) in the nucleus?", back: "Nuclear Binding Energy", subject: "Nuclear Physics" },

    { id: "3935", front: "What is the term for a substance that slows down neutrons in a nuclear reactor to increase the probability of fission?", back: "Moderator", subject: "Nuclear Physics" },

  art: [
    { id: "4001", front: "What is the term for the large stone structures built in the Neolithic period (e.g., Stonehenge)?", back: "Megaliths", subject: "Prehistoric" },
    { id: "4002", front: "What famous prehistoric site in France features detailed cave paintings of bison and horses?", back: "Lascaux Cave", subject: "Paleolithic" },
    { id: "4003", front: "What small, female figurine from the Paleolithic era is often seen as a fertility symbol?", back: "Venus of Willendorf", subject: "Paleolithic" },
    { id: "4004", front: "What civilization developed Cuneiform writing and built Ziggurats in Mesopotamia?", back: "Sumerian", subject: "Ancient Near East" },
    { id: "4005", front: "What is the name of the stepped temple structure typical of Ancient Mesopotamia?", back: "Ziggurat", subject: "Ancient Near East" },
    { id: "4006", front: "What monumental structure served as the tomb for the Egyptian Pharaoh Khufu?", back: "The Great Pyramid of Giza", subject: "Ancient Egypt" },
    { id: "4007", front: "What is the name of the Egyptian writing system composed of picture symbols?", back: "Hieroglyphs", subject: "Ancient Egypt" },
    { id: "4008", front: "What Egyptian convention depicts figures with their head, hips, arms, and legs in profile, but the eye and torso frontal?", back: "Frontalism (or Composite View)", subject: "Ancient Egypt" },
    { id: "4009", front: "What Aegean civilization built the Palace of Knossos and focused on sea life in their art?", back: "Minoan", subject: "Aegean" },
    { id: "4010", front: "What ancient Greek pottery shape was used for storing wine or oil, featuring a neck and two handles?", back: "Amphora", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4011", front: "What is the name for the period in Greek art (c. 600-480 BCE) characterized by rigid, frontal statues?", back: "Archaic period", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4012", front: "What is the term for the relaxed, natural pose developed in Classical Greek sculpture, where weight shifts to one leg?", back: "Contrapposto", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4013", front: "Who was the sculptor of the Doryphoros (Spear Bearer), embodying the 'Canon' of ideal human proportions?", back: "Polykleitos", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4014", front: "What Athenian temple, dedicated to the goddess Athena, is the pinnacle of Classical Greek architecture?", back: "The Parthenon", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4015", front: "What Greek architectural order is known for its simple, sturdy columns with a plain capital?", back: "Doric Order", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4016", front: "What Greek architectural order is characterized by scrolls (volutes) on the capital?", back: "Ionic Order", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4017", front: "What is the most ornate Greek architectural order, featuring stylized acanthus leaves on the capital?", back: "Corinthian Order", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4018", front: "What is the name for the realistic portraiture style favored by the Romans, emphasizing age and wisdom?", back: "Verism", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4019", front: "What Roman structure, famous for its perfect dome and oculus, was originally a temple to all gods?", back: "The Pantheon", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4020", front: "What Roman engineering innovation allowed for the construction of large spans, like the Colosseum?", back: "The Arch and Concrete", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4021", front: "What monumental arch in Rome commemorated Emperor Titus's victory in the Jewish War?", back: "Arch of Titus", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4022", front: "What art form, made by arranging small pieces of colored stone or glass, was widely used in Roman and Byzantine interiors?", back: "Mosaic", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4023", front: "What is the name for the large Roman public building used for law courts and often adopted for early Christian churches?", back: "Basilica", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4024", front: "The 'Palette of Narmer' is a significant artifact from which ancient culture?", back: "Ancient Egypt (Predynastic Period)", subject: "Ancient Egypt" },
    { id: "4025", front: "What term describes the massive gateway structures that form the entrances to Egyptian temples?", back: "Pylon", subject: "Ancient Egypt" },
    { id: "4026", front: "What civilization built the Great Sphinx?", back: "Ancient Egyptian (Old Kingdom)", subject: "Ancient Egypt" },
    { id: "4027", front: "What material did the Romans use extensively to build durable, large-scale structures like the Pantheon?", back: "Concrete", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4028", front: "What is the term for the upper part of a wall that contains windows, especially found in a basilica?", back: "Clerestory", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4029", front: "What is the name of the Hellenistic sculpture group depicting a priest and his sons being strangled by sea serpents?", back: "Laocoön and His Sons", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4030", front: "What architectural element is a row of columns surrounding a building or courtyard?", back: "Peristyle", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4031", front: "What is the term for a circular opening in the ceiling of a dome (as seen in the Pantheon)?", back: "Oculus", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4032", front: "What artifact containing three scripts allowed for the decipherment of Egyptian hieroglyphs?", back: "Rosetta Stone", subject: "Ancient Egypt" },
    { id: "4033", front: "Who commissioned the construction of the Parthenon?", back: "Pericles", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4034", front: "What is the artistic convention of depicting the most important figures as the largest (e.g., Egyptian Pharaohs)?", back: "Hierarchical Scale", subject: "Art Theory" },
    { id: "4035", front: "What is the term for the large burial mound or chamber tomb of the Mycenaean civilization?", back: "Tholos Tomb (or Beehive tomb)", subject: "Aegean" },
    { id: "4036", front: "The Code of Hammurabi is a significant artistic and legal artifact from which civilization?", back: "Babylonian", subject: "Ancient Near East" },
    { id: "4037", front: "What is the earliest known form of writing?", back: "Cuneiform", subject: "Ancient Near East" },
    { id: "4038", front: "What Greek architectural element is the triangular area above the entablature, typically filled with sculpture?", back: "Pediment", subject: "Ancient Greece" },
    { id: "4039", front: "What is the term for a long, narrative sculpture placed on the facade of a temple or building?", back: "Frieze", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4040", front: "What is the technique of applying pigments to wet plaster, used extensively in Minoan and Roman art?", back: "Fresco", subject: "Painting" },
    { id: "4041", front: "What is the term for the destruction of images or idols, a major event in Byzantine art history?", back: "Iconoclasm", subject: "Byzantine" },
    { id: "4042", front: "What is the name of the massive defensive wall in Beijing, China, built to protect against invasions?", back: "The Great Wall of China", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4043", front: "What Indian landmark is a massive domed shrine, originally built to hold the relics of the Buddha?", back: "Stupa", subject: "Asian Art" },
    { id: "4044", front: "What is the term for the decorative, intricate writing style common in Islamic art?", back: "Calligraphy", subject: "Islamic Art" },
    { id: "4045", front: "What culture is responsible for the Olmec heads—massive stone sculptures of human heads?", back: "Olmec", subject: "Mesoamerican" },
    { id: "4046", front: "What civilization built the city of Teotihuacan, featuring the Pyramid of the Sun and the Pyramid of the Moon?", back: "Teotihuacan (Pre-Aztec)", subject: "Mesoamerican" },
    { id: "4047", front: "What is the term for a tall, four-sided, narrow tapering monument which ends in a pyramid-like shape at the top?", back: "Obelisk", subject: "Ancient Egypt" },
    { id: "4048", front: "What Roman structure was primarily used for chariot races and other public events?", back: "Circus Maximus", subject: "Ancient Rome" },
    { id: "4049", front: "What term describes the art created by people who do not have a written language or have recently developed one?", back: "Pre-literate Art (or Tribal Art)", subject: "Art Theory" },
    { id: "4050", front: "The Lion Gate and the Treasury of Atreus are key sites for which Bronze Age Greek culture?", back: "Mycenaean", subject: "Aegean" },
    { id: "4051", front: "What is the dominant art form of the Byzantine Empire, characterized by religious figures with large eyes and gold backgrounds?", back: "Icon (panel painting) and Mosaic", subject: "Byzantine" },
    { id: "4052", front: "What is the name of the church in Ravenna, Italy, famous for its elaborate Byzantine mosaics of Emperor Justinian and Empress Theodora?", back: "San Vitale", subject: "Byzantine" },
    { id: "4053", front: "What is the term for the large, circular window found above the entrance of a Gothic cathedral?", back: "Rose Window", subject: "Gothic" },
    { id: "4054", front: "What architectural innovation transferred the weight of the nave's walls outward, allowing for thinner walls and larger windows?", back: "Flying Buttress", subject: "Gothic" },
    { id: "4055", front: "What is the name for the period (c. 1000-1200 CE) characterized by thick walls, rounded arches, and barrel vaults in church architecture?", back: "Romanesque", subject: "Medieval" },
    { id: "4056", front: "What is the semi-circular area above the main entrance door of a Romanesque or Gothic church, typically filled with sculpture?", back: "Tympanum", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4057", front: "What is the name for the richly decorated, hand-written books produced in the Middle Ages?", back: "Illuminated Manuscripts", subject: "Medieval" },
    { id: "4058", front: "What is the term for the art style of the nomadic tribes of Northern Europe, characterized by intricate interlacing patterns and animal motifs?", back: "Insular Art (or Hiberno-Saxon)", subject: "Early Medieval" },
    { id: "4059", front: "What famous manuscript is a key example of Insular Art, created in a Scottish monastery (c. 800 CE)?", back: "The Book of Kells", subject: "Early Medieval" },
    { id: "4060", front: "What style, beginning in the mid-12th century, is known for its lightness, verticality, pointed arches, and stained glass?", back: "Gothic", subject: "Medieval" },
    { id: "4061", front: "What famous French cathedral is often cited as the definitive example of High Gothic architecture?", back: "Chartres Cathedral (Notre Dame de Chartres)", subject: "Gothic" },
    { id: "4062", front: "What is the term for the technique of cutting pieces of colored glass and joining them with lead strips to form an image?", back: "Stained Glass", subject: "Gothic" },
    { id: "4063", front: "What is the central, main aisle of a basilica or church called?", back: "Nave", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4064", front: "What part of a cruciform church forms the 'arms' of the cross?", back: "Transept", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4065", front: "What is the name of the famous tapestry (though technically an embroidery) depicting the Norman conquest of England?", back: "Bayeux Tapestry", subject: "Romanesque" },
    { id: "4066", front: "What is the term for a small room or cubicle in a Roman catacomb used for private burial, often decorated with frescos?", back: "Cubiculum", subject: "Early Christian" },
    { id: "4067", front: "What famous structure in Istanbul (Constantinople) was originally a Byzantine church, then a mosque, and now a museum?", back: "Hagia Sophia", subject: "Byzantine" },
    { id: "4068", front: "What is the term for the area surrounding the altar, often containing the apse, transept, and choir?", back: "Chancel (or Choir)", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4069", front: "What architectural form is created when two barrel vaults intersect at a right angle?", back: "Groin Vault (or Cross Vault)", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4070", front: "What is the term for a piece of clothing, bone, or object venerated because of its association with a saint or martyr?", back: "Relic", subject: "Medieval" },
    { id: "4071", front: "What is the architectural feature—a bell tower—often detached from the main church structure?", back: "Campanile", subject: "Architecture" },
    { id: "4072", front: "What is the name for the large, open space in a monastery, typically featuring a garden and a covered walkway?", back: "Cloister", subject: "Medieval" },
    { id: "4073", front: "What type of religious art, often featuring a highly stylized figure of Christ on the cross, was characteristic of the German Gothic period?", back: "Crucifix (or Gero Cross)", subject: "Medieval" },
    { id: "4074", front: "What art form, typically created on wooden panels with egg yolk as a binder, dominated Byzantine and Early Italian art?", back: "Tempera painting", subject: "Painting" },

    { id: "4462", front: "What is the term for a thick application of paint, making the texture stand out from the canvas?", back: "Impasto", subject: "Art Technique" },

    { "id": "7260", "front": "What is the name for a molecule that contains both a hydrophobic and a hydrophilic region (e.g., a phospholipid)?", "back": "Amphipathic (or Amphiphilic)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7261", "front": "What is the overall term for all the chemical reactions that occur within a living organism?", "back": "Metabolism", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7262", "front": "What is the metabolic process of breaking down molecules to release energy?", "back": "Catabolism", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7263", "front": "What is the metabolic process of building up larger molecules from smaller ones, requiring energy?", "back": "Anabolism", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7264", "front": "What is the name for the molecule $\text{ATP}$?", "back": "Adenosine Triphosphate", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7265", "front": "What is the major difference in function between $\text{DNA}$ and $\text{RNA}$?", "back": "DNA stores genetic info; RNA transmits and expresses it", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7266", "front": "What are the four common nitrogenous bases in $\text{DNA}$?", "back": "Adenine (A), Guanine (G), Cytosine (C), Thymine (T)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7267", "front": "What is the name for the bond that holds the two strands of the DNA double helix together?", "back": "Hydrogen Bonds", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7268", "front": "What is the name for the common polymer known as 'Plexiglas' (poly(methyl methacrylate))?", "back": "PMMA", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7269", "front": "What type of polymer is formed by the simple addition of monomers to a growing chain (usually involves double bonds)?", "back": "Addition Polymer", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7270", "front": "What type of polymer is formed by the linking of monomers with the simultaneous loss of a small molecule (like $\text{H}_2\text{O}$)?", "back": "Condensation Polymer", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7271", "front": "What common condensation polymer is formed from a dicarboxylic acid and a diamine?", "back": "Nylon (Polyamide)", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7272", "front": "What common condensation polymer is formed from a dicarboxylic acid and a diol?", "back": "Polyester", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7273", "front": "What is the term for the large number of atoms that are chemically bonded together into a single, continuous network (e.g., diamond, quartz)?", "back": "Network Covalent Solid (or Covalent Network)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7274", "front": "What type of solid is held together by weak intermolecular forces (e.g., ice, dry ice)?", "back": "Molecular Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7275", "front": "What type of solid is held together by strong electrostatic attractions between positive and negative ions (e.g., $\text{NaCl}$)?", "back": "Ionic Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7276", "front": "What type of solid is composed of positive metal ions surrounded by a sea of delocalized electrons (e.g., copper)?", "back": "Metallic Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7277", "front": "What property of metals allows them to conduct electricity and heat well?", "back": "Delocalized Electrons (Sea of Electrons)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7278", "front": "What is the term for a mixture of two or more elements, at least one of which is a metal, and the resulting material retains metallic properties?", "back": "Alloy", "subject": "Mixtures" },
    { "id": "7279", "front": "What is the common name for the alloy of iron and carbon?", "back": "Steel", "subject": "Mixtures" },
    { "id": "7280", "front": "What is the common name for the alloy of copper and zinc?", "back": "Brass", "subject": "Mixtures" },
    { "id": "7281", "front": "What is the unit for electric potential difference (or voltage)?", "back": "Volt ($\text{V}$)", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7282", "front": "What is the unit for resistance?", "back": "Ohm ($\Omega$)", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7283", "front": "What is the unit for power, which is equal to Joules per second ($\text{J/s}$)?", "back": "Watt ($\text{W}$)", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7284", "front": "What is the equation that relates standard cell potential ($\text{E}^\circ$) to the equilibrium constant ($\text{K}$)?", "back": "$-nF\text{E}^\circ = -RT\ln K$ (or $\text{E}^\circ = \frac{RT}{nF}\ln K$)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7285", "front": "What is the equation that relates cell potential ($\text{E}$) to non-standard concentrations/pressures (Q)?", "back": "Nernst Equation ($\text{E} = \text{E}^\circ - \frac{RT}{nF}\ln Q$)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7286", "front": "What is the term for an electrochemical cell that operates at non-standard conditions (i.e., concentrations are not $1 \text{ M}$)?", "back": "Concentration Cell", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7287", "front": "What is the term for a battery that is designed to be recharged by reversing the flow of electricity?", "back": "Secondary Cell (or Rechargeable Battery)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7288", "front": "What is the term for a battery that is designed to be used once and discarded?", "back": "Primary Cell (or Non-rechargeable Battery)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7289", "front": "What is the process of coating an object with a thin layer of metal using electrolysis?", "back": "Electroplating", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7290", "front": "What is the overall term for the energy required to make a reaction go forward or backward?", "back": "Gibbs Free Energy ($\Delta G$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7291", "front": "What law states that if a reaction is reversed, the sign of $\Delta H$ is reversed?", "back": "Hess's Law (specifically, the property of state functions)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7292", "front": "What is the term for the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a substance by $1^\circ\text{C}$?", "back": "Heat Capacity ($\text{C}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7293", "front": "What is the term for the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of $\mathbf{1 \text{ gram}}$ of a substance by $1^\circ\text{C}$?", "back": "Specific Heat Capacity ($c$ or $s$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7294", "front": "What is the equation used to calculate heat transfer ($q$) involving mass, specific heat, and temperature change?", "back": "$q = mc\Delta T$", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7295", "front": "What type of glassware is used to precisely measure the volume of liquid dispensed in a titration?", "back": "Buret", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7296", "front": "What type of glassware is used to prepare solutions of known concentration accurately?", "back": "Volumetric Flask", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7297", "front": "What is the technique used to determine the concentration of a substance by comparing its light absorption to a known standard?", "back": "Spectrophotometry (or Colorimetry)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7298", "front": "What law relates the absorbance of light to the concentration of the substance and the path length of the light?", "back": "Beer-Lambert Law ($\text{A} = \epsilon\text{lc}$)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7299", "front": "What is the term for a substance that can change its color or appearance when exposed to light (often used in photography)?", "back": "Photochromic (or Photosensitive)", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7300", "front": "What is the term for the amount of energy required to convert one mole of liquid to gas at its boiling point?", "back": "Molar Heat of Vaporization ($\Delta H_{vap}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7301", "front": "What is the term for the amount of energy required to convert one mole of solid to liquid at its melting point?", "back": "Molar Heat of Fusion ($\Delta H_{fus}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7302", "front": "What is the term for the difference between the energy of the products and the energy of the reactants?", "back": "Enthalpy of Reaction ($\Delta H_{rxn}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7303", "front": "What is the term for a gas that has had its temperature lowered below its critical temperature so that it can be liquefied by pressure?", "back": "Vapor", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7304", "front": "What is the common term for a high-pressure, high-temperature fluid above the critical point?", "back": "Supercritical Fluid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7305", "front": "What is the term for the temperature at which a liquid's vapor pressure equals the external pressure?", "back": "Boiling Point", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7306", "front": "What is the term for the phenomenon where a gas leaks out of a container through a very small hole?", "back": "Effusion", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7307", "front": "What is the process of gases mixing spontaneously as a result of random motion?", "back": "Diffusion", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7308", "front": "What law describes the rate of effusion of gases?", "back": "Graham's Law (of Effusion)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7309", "front": "What is the volume occupied by one mole of an ideal gas at $1 \text{ atm}$ and $25^\circ\text{C}$ (Standard Ambient Temperature and Pressure - $\text{SATP}$)?", "back": "24.46 L", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7310", "front": "What is the value of the Ideal Gas Constant ($\text{R}$)?", "back": "$0.08206 \text{ L} \cdot \text{atm} / (\text{mol} \cdot \text{K})$ (or $8.314 \text{ J} / (\text{mol} \cdot \text{K})$)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7311", "front": "What is the term for the reaction between a nonmetal oxide (like $\text{CO}_2$) and water?", "back": "Acid Anhydride Reaction (forms an acid)", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7312", "front": "What is the term for the reaction between a metal oxide (like $\text{Na}_2\text{O}$) and water?", "back": "Basic Anhydride Reaction (forms a base)", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7313", "front": "What is the formula for the strong acid **Nitric Acid**?", "back": "$\text{HNO}_3$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7314", "front": "What is the formula for the strong acid **Hydrochloric Acid**?", "back": "$\text{HCl}$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7315", "front": "What is the formula for the strong acid **Sulfuric Acid**?", "back": "$\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7316", "front": "What is the formula for the weak acid **Acetic Acid** (vinegar)?", "back": "$\text{CH}_3\text{COOH}$ (or $\text{HC}_2\text{H}_3\text{O}_2$)", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7317", "front": "What is the name for the compound $\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4$?", "back": "Sodium Sulfate", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7318", "front": "What is the name for the compound $\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3$?", "back": "Iron(III) Oxide (Rust)", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7319", "front": "What is the formula for the polyatomic ion **Carbonate**?", "back": "$\text{CO}_3^{2-}$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7320", "front": "What is the formula for the polyatomic ion **Hydroxide**?", "back": "$\text{OH}^{-}$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7321", "front": "What is the formula for the polyatomic ion **Bicarbonate** (Hydrogen Carbonate)?", "back": "$\text{HCO}_3^{-}$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7322", "front": "What is the name for the compound $\text{Cu}(\text{NO}_3)_2$?", "back": "Copper(II) Nitrate", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7323", "front": "What type of chemical equation includes the physical states of all reactants and products?", "back": "Complete Chemical Equation", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7324", "front": "What is the term for a substance that can react with both acids and bases (e.g., $\text{Al}_2\text{O}_3$)?", "back": "Amphoteric Substance", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7325", "front": "What is the term for a substance that can be oxidized or reduced in a redox reaction?", "back": "Redox Agent (or Oxidizing/Reducing Agent)", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7326", "front": "What is the oxidation state of hydrogen in metal hydrides (e.g., $\text{NaH}$)?", "back": "$-1$", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7327", "front": "What is the most common oxidation state of oxygen in compounds?", "back": "$-2$", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7328", "front": "What is the oxidation state of any uncombined element?", "back": "$0$", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7329", "front": "What is the study of the structure and properties of atomic nuclei?", "back": "Nuclear Chemistry", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7330", "front": "What is the term for the process where an unstable nucleus loses energy by emitting radiation?", "back": "Radioactive Decay (or Nuclear Decay)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7331", "front": "What is the type of nuclear decay that releases a helium nucleus?", "back": "Alpha Decay", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7332", "front": "What is the type of nuclear decay that converts a neutron into a proton and an electron?", "back": "Beta Decay (or $\beta^{-}$ decay)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7333", "front": "What is the term for the energy required to initiate nuclear fusion?", "back": "Fusion Barrier (or Coulomb Barrier)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7334", "front": "What is the term for the change in mass that occurs when a nucleus is formed from its component nucleons?", "back": "Mass Defect", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7335", "front": "What is the most common use of Carbon-14 ($\text{C}-14$)?", "back": "Radiocarbon Dating", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7336", "front": "What type of decay is used in $\text{PET}$ (Positron Emission Tomography) scans?", "back": "Positron Emission", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7337", "front": "What term describes the energy required to break all the bonds in a chemical compound?", "back": "Total Bond Energy (or Enthalpy of Atomization)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7338", "front": "What is the energy released when a mole of solute dissolves in a solvent?", "back": "Enthalpy of Solution ($\Delta H_{soln}$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7339", "front": "What is the energy change when a gaseous ion dissolves in water?", "back": "Enthalpy of Hydration ($\Delta H_{hyd}$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7340", "front": "What is the overall energy change in the Born-Haber cycle for the formation of an ionic compound?", "back": "Standard Enthalpy of Formation ($\Delta H_f^\circ$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7341", "front": "What is the term for the process of determining the purity of a substance?", "back": "Assay (or Purity Analysis)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7342", "front": "What is the common term for the substance that is being analyzed in an analytical procedure?", "back": "Analyte", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7343", "front": "What is the term for the minimum amount of solute required to form a detectable precipitate?", "back": "Ion Product ($Q_{sp}$)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7344", "front": "If $\text{Q}_{sp} > \text{K}_{sp}$, what happens to the solution?", "back": "Precipitation occurs", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7345", "front": "What is the term for a substance that can act as a reducing agent in one reaction and an oxidizing agent in another?", "back": "Amphoteric (or Disproportionation Agent)", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7346", "front": "What is the reducing agent in the reaction: $\text{Zn} + \text{Cu}^{2+} \to \text{Zn}^{2+} + \text{Cu}$?", "back": "$\text{Zn}$ (Zinc metal)", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7347", "front": "What is the oxidizing agent in the reaction: $\text{Zn} + \text{Cu}^{2+} \to \text{Zn}^{2+} + \text{Cu}$?", "back": "$\text{Cu}^{2+}$ (Copper(II) ion)", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7348", "front": "What is the term for the time it takes for the concentration of a reactant to decrease to half its initial value?", "back": "Half-life ($t_{1/2}$)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7349", "front": "For a first-order reaction, how does the half-life depend on the initial concentration?", "back": "It is independent of the initial concentration", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7350", "front": "For a second-order reaction, how does the half-life depend on the initial concentration?", "back": "It is inversely proportional to the initial concentration", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7351", "front": "What is the term for the overall chemical reaction that includes all the elementary steps in a mechanism?", "back": "Net Reaction (or Overall Reaction)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7352", "front": "What is the term for a reaction that involves the substitution of a hydrogen atom by a halogen ($\text{F, Cl, Br, I}$)?", "back": "Halogenation (Substitution)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7353", "front": "What is the general term for a hydrocarbon that contains a ring structure?", "back": "Cyclic Hydrocarbon", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7354", "front": "What is the term for the simple, single-bonded group $\text{CH}_3$-?", "back": "Methyl Group", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7355", "front": "What is the term for the simple, single-bonded group $\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2$-?", "back": "Ethyl Group", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7356", "front": "What is the term for the process of breaking down a long-chain alkane into smaller, more useful hydrocarbons?", "back": "Cracking", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7357", "front": "What is the term for a protein that has lost its three-dimensional structure (and thus its function)?", "back": "Denatured Protein", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7358", "front": "What is the term for the complex, functional arrangement of multiple protein subunits (e.g., hemoglobin)?", "back": "Quaternary Structure", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7359", "front": "What are the three components of a nucleotide?", "back": "Nitrogenous Base, Phosphate Group, Pentose Sugar", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7360", "front": "What is the major difference between the nitrogenous bases in $\text{DNA}$ and $\text{RNA}$?", "back": "DNA has Thymine (T), RNA has Uracil (U)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7361", "front": "What is the name for the polymer of simple sugars used for energy storage in plants?", "back": "Starch", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7362", "front": "What is the name for the polymer of simple sugars used for energy storage in animals?", "back": "Glycogen", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7363", "front": "What is the name for the structural polymer of simple sugars found in plant cell walls?", "back": "Cellulose", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7364", "front": "What is the phenomenon where a colloidal mixture scatters light?", "back": "Tyndall Effect", "subject": "Mixtures" },
    { "id": "7365", "front": "What is the term for a homogeneous mixture with particles larger than a solution but smaller than a suspension?", "back": "Colloid (or Colloidal Dispersion)", "subject": "Mixtures" },
    { "id": "7366", "front": "What is the term for the random, erratic movement of colloidal particles (prevents settling)?", "back": "Brownian Motion", "subject": "Mixtures" },
    { "id": "7367", "front": "What is the term for the process of using an electric charge to cause a colloid to precipitate?", "back": "Coagulation (or Flocculation)", "subject": "Mixtures" },
    { "id": "7368", "front": "What is the term for a substance that can lower the surface tension of a liquid (e.g., soap)?", "back": "Surfactant", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7369", "front": "What is the term for the measure of a liquid's ability to resist changes in its internal $\text{pH}$?", "back": "Buffer Capacity", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7370", "front": "What is the measure of how strongly a specific acid ionizes in water ($\text{K}_\text{a}$)?", "back": "Acid Dissociation Constant", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7371", "front": "What is the measure of how strongly a specific base ionizes in water ($\text{K}_\text{b}$)?", "back": "Base Dissociation Constant", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7372", "front": "What is the relationship between $\text{K}_\text{a}$ and $\text{K}_\text{b}$ for a conjugate acid-base pair?", "back": "$K_a \cdot K_b = K_w$", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7373", "front": "What is the general name for a chemical species that can undergo substitution, addition, or elimination reactions?", "back": "Organic Reactant (or Substrate)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7374", "front": "What is the term for a reagent that is attracted to electron-rich centers (often positively charged)?", "back": "Electrophile", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7375", "front": "What is the term for a reagent that is attracted to electron-poor centers (often negatively charged or has lone pairs)?", "back": "Nucleophile", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7376", "front": "What is the term for the difference between the actual mass of an atom and the sum of the masses of its constituent protons and neutrons?", "back": "Mass Defect", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7377", "front": "What is the process that occurs in the sun, combining light nuclei to form heavier ones?", "back": "Nuclear Fusion", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7378", "front": "What type of radioactive decay results in the mass number remaining unchanged but the atomic number increasing by one?", "back": "Beta Decay ($\beta^{-}$)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7379", "front": "What type of radioactive decay results in the mass number decreasing by four and the atomic number decreasing by two?", "back": "Alpha Decay ($\alpha$)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7380", "front": "What is the phenomenon where the rate of a chemical reaction is proportional to the probability of molecules colliding in the correct orientation and energy?", "back": "Collision Theory", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7381", "front": "What is the term for the minimum number of atoms that can crystallize to form a unit cell (smallest repeating unit)?", "back": "Unit Cell", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7382", "front": "What is the term for the complete, repeating geometric arrangement of particles in a crystalline solid?", "back": "Crystal Lattice", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7383", "front": "What is the term for the process where a solid turns directly into a liquid?", "back": "Melting (or Fusion)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7384", "front": "What is the term for the process where a liquid turns directly into a solid?", "back": "Freezing (or Solidification)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7385", "front": "What type of chemical equation includes all soluble ionic compounds written as dissociated ions?", "back": "Complete Ionic Equation", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7386", "front": "What is the term for the ions that are present on both the reactant and product sides of a complete ionic equation?", "back": "Spectator Ions", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7387", "front": "What is the term for the overall chemical equation excluding spectator ions?", "back": "Net Ionic Equation", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7388", "front": "What is the general term for a substance that dissolves in a solvent to form a solution?", "back": "Solute", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7389", "front": "What is the general term for the substance that dissolves the solute to form a solution?", "back": "Solvent", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7390", "front": "What is the general rule of thumb for predicting solubility based on polarity?", "back": "Like Dissolves Like", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7391", "front": "What is the term for the process of separating a liquid from a solution by boiling and then condensing the vapor?", "back": "Distillation", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7392", "front": "What is the term for the separation technique based on distributing components between two immiscible liquids?", "back": "Liquid-Liquid Extraction", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7393", "front": "What is the name for the technique used to determine the concentration of an unknown solution by reacting it with a known solution?", "back": "Titration", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7394", "front": "What is the common term for a solution where the $\text{pH}$ equals the $\text{pKa}$ of the weak acid component?", "back": "Optimal Buffer ($\text{[Acid]} = \text{[Base]}$)", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7395", "front": "What is the mathematical definition of $\text{pKa}$?", "back": "$-\log(\text{K}_\text{a})$", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7396", "front": "How does the acid strength relate to the $\text{pKa}$ value?", "back": "Lower $\text{pKa}$ means stronger acid", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7397", "front": "What is the term for a solution that contains the maximum amount of solute possible at a given temperature?", "back": "Saturated Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7398", "front": "What happens if a seed crystal is added to a supersaturated solution?", "back": "Excess solute precipitates out (Crystallization)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7399", "front": "What is the relationship between the $\text{K}_\text{sp}$ value and the solubility of an ionic compound?", "back": "Higher $\text{K}_\text{sp}$ means higher solubility", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7400", "front": "What is the general term for the study of the flow of heat?", "back": "Calorimetry", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7401", "front": "What law states that the standard cell potential is the sum of the standard reduction and oxidation potentials?", "back": "Electrochemical Law (part of Hess's Law for $\Delta G$)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7402", "front": "What is the term for the potential difference developed by an electrochemical cell when it is operating under standard conditions?", "back": "Standard Cell Potential ($\text{E}^\circ_{cell}$)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7403", "front": "What is the SI unit for the quantity of heat or energy?", "back": "Joule ($\text{J}$)", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7404", "front": "What is the SI unit for electric charge?", "back": "Coulomb ($\text{C}$)", "subject": "General" },

    { "id": "7525", "front": "How does metallic character generally change as you move **across** a period (left to right) on the periodic table?", "back": "Decreases", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },

    { "id": "7534", "front": "In the Bohr model, when an electron moves from a higher to a lower energy orbit, is a photon absorbed or emitted?", "back": "Emitted", "subject": "Atomic Structure" },
    { "id": "7535", "front": "What is the term for the region of space around the nucleus where an electron is likely to be found?", "back": "Atomic Orbital", "subject": "Atomic Structure" },

    { "id": "7548", "front": "What is the hybridization of the central atom in an octahedral geometry?", "back": "$sp^3d^2$", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7549", "front": "What type of intermolecular force is present in **all** molecules (polar and nonpolar)?", "back": "London Dispersion Forces (LDF)", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7550", "front": "What type of intermolecular force exists between two temporary dipoles?", "back": "London Dispersion Forces (LDF)", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7551", "front": "What is the term for the total energy content of a system at constant volume?", "back": "Internal Energy ($\text{E}$ or $\text{U}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7552", "front": "What is the term for the heat content of a system at constant pressure?", "back": "Enthalpy ($\text{H}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7553", "front": "What is the term for the heat absorbed when a gas condenses to a liquid?", "back": "Molar Heat of Condensation ($\Delta H_{cond}$) (Negative of $\Delta H_{vap}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7554", "front": "What is the term for the heat released when a liquid solidifies to a solid?", "back": "Molar Heat of Freezing ($\Delta H_{freeze}$) (Negative of $\Delta H_{fus}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7555", "front": "What is the term for the heat released when one mole of a compound is formed from its elements in their standard states?", "back": "Standard Enthalpy of Formation ($\Delta H_f^\circ$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7556", "front": "What is the value of $\Delta H_f^\circ$ for a pure element in its standard state (e.g., $\text{O}_2(g)$ or $\text{C}(s, \text{graphite})$)?", "back": "$0 \text{ kJ/mol}$", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7557", "front": "What is the unit of $k$ for a second-order reaction?", "back": "$\text{M}^{-1}\text{s}^{-1}$ (or $\text{L} \cdot \text{mol}^{-1} \cdot \text{s}^{-1}$)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7558", "front": "What is the unit of $k$ for a zero-order reaction?", "back": "$\text{M} \cdot \text{s}^{-1}$ (or $\text{mol} \cdot \text{L}^{-1} \cdot \text{s}^{-1}$)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7559", "front": "What is the common term for the substance that acts as the container and surrounding in a calorimetry experiment?", "back": "Surroundings (often the water/solvent)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7560", "front": "What is the term for the sum of the powers of the concentration terms in the rate law?", "back": "Overall Reaction Order", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7561", "front": "What is the term for the step in a reaction mechanism that is much slower than the other steps?", "back": "Rate-Determining Step (RDS)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7562", "front": "What is the term for a substance that increases the rate of a reaction without being consumed itself?", "back": "Catalyst", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7563", "front": "How does a catalyst affect the $\Delta H$ and $E_a$ of a reaction?", "back": "It lowers $E_a$ but does not change $\Delta H$", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7564", "front": "What is the term for the equilibrium constant for the autoionization of water ($\text{H}_2\text{O}$)?", "back": "$K_w$ (Ion-Product Constant for Water)", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7565", "front": "In a basic solution, how does $\text{[OH}^{-}]$ compare to $\text{[H}^+]$?", "back": "$[\text{OH}^{-}] > [\text{H}^+]$", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7566", "front": "What is the $\text{pH}$ of a neutral solution at $25^\circ\text{C}$?", "back": "$7.00$", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7567", "front": "What is the name for a diprotic acid that has one proton removed?", "back": "Hydrogen $\dots$ (e.g., Hydrogen Sulfate, $\text{HSO}_4^{-}$)", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7568", "front": "What is the term for a buffer solution that has $\text{[weak acid]} \approx \text{[conjugate base]}$?", "back": "Optimal Buffer", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7569", "front": "What is the term for the specific point in a titration where the moles of acid exactly equal the moles of base added?", "back": "Equivalence Point (or Stoichiometric Point)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7570", "front": "What is the term for the point in a titration where the indicator changes color?", "back": "End Point", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7571", "front": "What is the name for the separation technique that relies on the difference in volatility (boiling point)?", "back": "Distillation", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7572", "front": "What is the term for the ratio of the solubility of a solute in two immiscible solvents (used in extraction)?", "back": "Partition Coefficient (or Distribution Coefficient)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7573", "front": "What is the general name for the device used to measure the absorbance of light by a solution?", "back": "Spectrophotometer (or Colorimeter)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7574", "front": "What is the name for the graph of absorbance versus concentration, used to determine unknown concentrations?", "back": "Calibration Curve (or Standard Curve)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7575", "front": "What is the general term for the measure of the difference between an experimental value and the true value?", "back": "Accuracy (Error)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7576", "front": "What is the general term for the measure of how closely repeated measurements agree with each other?", "back": "Precision", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7577", "front": "What is the common term for a volume-measuring device used to deliver a single, precise volume of liquid?", "back": "Volumetric Pipet", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7578", "front": "What is the common term for a volume-measuring device used to measure and deliver variable volumes of liquid?", "back": "Graduated Cylinder (or Measuring Pipet)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7579", "front": "What is the term for the total mass of the products being exactly equal to the total mass of the reactants?", "back": "Law of Conservation of Mass", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7580", "front": "What is the term for the observation that a chemical compound always contains the same elements in the same proportions by mass?", "back": "Law of Definite Proportions", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7581", "front": "What is the term for the law that explains that when two elements form more than one compound, the masses of one element combine with a fixed mass of the second in ratios of small whole numbers?", "back": "Law of Multiple Proportions", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7582", "front": "What is the name of the theory that states that matter is composed of small, indivisible particles called atoms?", "back": "Dalton's Atomic Theory", "subject": "Atomic Structure" },
    { "id": "7583", "front": "What is the term for atoms of the same element that have different numbers of neutrons?", "back": "Isotopes", "subject": "Atomic Structure" },
    { "id": "7584", "front": "What is the term for atoms or ions of different elements that have the same total number of electrons?", "back": "Isoelectronic Species", "subject": "Atomic Structure" },
    { "id": "7585", "front": "What is the formula for the relationship between the speed of light ($c$), wavelength ($\lambda$), and frequency ($\nu$)?", "back": "$c = \lambda \nu$", "subject": "Atomic Structure" },
    { "id": "7586", "front": "What is the formula for the energy of a photon ($E$)?", "back": "$E = h\nu$ (or $E = hc/\lambda$)", "subject": "Atomic Structure" },
    { "id": "7587", "front": "What is the term for the ability of light to knock an electron out of a metal (threshold energy)?", "back": "Work Function ($\Phi$)", "subject": "Atomic Structure" },
    { "id": "7588", "front": "What is the term for the study of the structure, composition, and properties of matter and the changes it undergoes?", "back": "Chemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7589", "front": "What is the term for the study of matter that does not contain carbon?", "back": "Inorganic Chemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7590", "front": "What is the term for the study of compounds containing carbon?", "back": "Organic Chemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7591", "front": "What is the term for the study of the quantitative analysis of chemical substances?", "back": "Analytical Chemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7592", "front": "What is the term for the study of the relationship between heat and other forms of energy in chemical reactions?", "back": "Physical Chemistry (or Thermodynamics)", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7593", "front": "What is the term for the study of chemical processes within living organisms?", "back": "Biochemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7594", "front": "What is the common term for a species that has lost one or more electrons (making it positively charged)?", "back": "Cation", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7595", "front": "What is the common term for a species that has gained one or more electrons (making it negatively charged)?", "back": "Anion", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7596", "front": "What is the term for an ionic compound that contains water molecules within its crystal structure?", "back": "Hydrate", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7597", "front": "What is the term for an ionic compound that has had all water molecules removed from its structure?", "back": "Anhydrous Compound", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7598", "front": "What is the formula for the polyatomic ion **Phosphate**?", "back": "$\text{PO}_4^{3-}$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7599", "front": "What is the formula for the polyatomic ion **Sulfite**?", "back": "$\text{SO}_3^{2-}$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7600", "front": "What is the formula for the polyatomic ion **Hypochlorite** (active ingredient in bleach)?", "back": "$\text{ClO}^{-}$", "subject": "Nomenclature" },
    { "id": "7601", "front": "What is the term for the process of determining the empirical formula from percent composition?", "back": "Elemental Analysis (or Empirical Formula Determination)", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7602", "front": "What is the term for the simplest whole-number ratio of atoms in a compound?", "back": "Empirical Formula", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7603", "front": "What is the term for the actual number of atoms of each element in a molecule?", "back": "Molecular Formula", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7604", "front": "What is the term for a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a reaction?", "back": "Limiting Reactant", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7605", "front": "What is the term for a reactant that is not completely used up in a reaction?", "back": "Excess Reactant", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7606", "front": "What is the measure of the efficiency of a reaction (actual yield / theoretical yield $\times 100\%$)?", "back": "Percent Yield", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7607", "front": "What is the term for the amount of product that is predicted to be formed based on the stoichiometry of the reaction?", "back": "Theoretical Yield", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7608", "front": "What is the common term for the substance that is physically collected from a chemical reaction?", "back": "Actual Yield", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7609", "front": "What is the term for the standard conditions for a gas, defined as $0^\circ\text{C}$ ($\text{273.15 K}$) and $1 \text{ atm}$?", "back": "Standard Temperature and Pressure ($\text{STP}$)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7610", "front": "What is the term for the standard conditions used in thermodynamics, usually $25^\circ\text{C}$ ($\text{298.15 K}$) and $1 \text{ atm}$?", "back": "Standard Ambient Temperature and Pressure ($\text{SATP}$)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7611", "front": "What is the volume occupied by one mole of an ideal gas at $\text{STP}$?", "back": "$22.4 \text{ L}$", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7612", "front": "What is the term for the pressure exerted by one component of a mixture of gases?", "back": "Partial Pressure", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7613", "front": "What law states that the total pressure of a mixture of gases is the sum of the partial pressures of the individual gases?", "back": "Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7614", "front": "What is the term for the pressure exerted by a vapor in equilibrium with its liquid or solid phase?", "back": "Vapor Pressure", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7615", "front": "What is the term for the process of a liquid turning into a gas below its boiling point?", "back": "Evaporation", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7616", "front": "What is the name for the equation that relates the vapor pressure of a liquid to its temperature and enthalpy of vaporization?", "back": "Clausius-Clapeyron Equation", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7617", "front": "What is the general term for the process of a solid turning directly into a gas?", "back": "Sublimation", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7618", "front": "What is the general term for the process of a gas turning directly into a solid?", "back": "Deposition", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7619", "front": "What is the term for the plot of pressure vs. temperature that summarizes all phase equilibria for a substance?", "back": "Phase Diagram", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7620", "front": "What is the point on a phase diagram where all three phases (solid, liquid, gas) coexist at equilibrium?", "back": "Triple Point", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7621", "front": "What is the point on a phase diagram beyond which the distinction between liquid and gas phases disappears?", "back": "Critical Point", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7622", "front": "What is the general term for the study of the composition and structure of crystalline solids?", "back": "Crystallography", "subject": "States of Matter" },
