    { "id": "7624", "front": "What is the term for the arrangement of atoms in which the center of each atom is at a corner of the unit cell?", "back": "Simple Cubic (SC)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7625", "front": "What is the term for the arrangement of atoms in which the center of an atom is at each corner and one atom is in the center of the unit cell?", "back": "Body-Centered Cubic (BCC)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7626", "front": "What is the term for the arrangement of atoms in which the center of an atom is at each corner and one atom is in the center of each face of the unit cell?", "back": "Face-Centered Cubic (FCC)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7627", "front": "What is the term for the spontaneous process where a substance spreads out to occupy a larger volume (due to random motion)?", "back": "Diffusion", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7628", "front": "What law describes the rate of diffusion/effusion as inversely proportional to the square root of the molar mass?", "back": "Graham's Law", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7629", "front": "What is the term for the average kinetic energy of gas molecules, which is directly proportional to temperature?", "back": "Root-Mean-Square (RMS) Speed", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7630", "front": "What is the name for the equation that corrects the ideal gas law for intermolecular forces and finite molecular volume?", "back": "van der Waals Equation", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7631", "front": "What is the common term for a solution that resists changes in $\text{pH}$ upon the addition of small amounts of acid or base?", "back": "Buffer Solution", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7632", "front": "What equation is used to calculate the $\text{pH}$ of a buffer solution?", "back": "Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7633", "front": "What is the general term for a substance that changes color in response to a change in $\text{pH}$?", "back": "Acid-Base Indicator", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7634", "front": "What is the term for the point in a titration where the moles of the substance being titrated are precisely consumed?", "back": "Equivalence Point", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7635", "front": "What is the name for the graph of $\text{pH}$ vs. volume of titrant added?", "back": "Titration Curve", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7636", "front": "What is the major species present when a strong acid ($\text{HCl}$) is mixed with a strong base ($\text{NaOH}$) at the equivalence point?", "back": "Neutral Salt and Water ($\text{NaCl}$ and $\text{H}_2\text{O}$)", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7637", "front": "What is the major species present when a weak acid ($\text{CH}_3\text{COOH}$) is titrated with a strong base ($\text{NaOH}$) at the equivalence point?", "back": "Weak Conjugate Base ($\text{CH}_3\text{COO}^{-}$)", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7638", "front": "What is the $\text{pH}$ at the equivalence point of a strong acid/strong base titration?", "back": "$7.00$", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7639", "front": "What is the $\text{pH}$ at the equivalence point of a weak acid/strong base titration?", "back": "Greater than $7.00$ (Basic)", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7640", "front": "What is the $\text{pH}$ at the equivalence point of a strong acid/weak base titration?", "back": "Less than $7.00$ (Acidic)", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7641", "front": "What is the term for the energy required to remove an electron from a gaseous species (related to the $\text{O}$ in $\text{OILRIG}$)?", "back": "Ionization Energy", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7642", "front": "What is the term for the spontaneous process that occurs in a Galvanic cell, producing electrical energy?", "back": "Redox Reaction (Spontaneous)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7643", "front": "What is the name for the electrode where **oxidation** occurs?", "back": "Anode", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7644", "front": "What is the name for the electrode where **reduction** occurs?", "back": "Cathode", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7645", "front": "In a Galvanic cell, which electrode is typically negative and which is positive?", "back": "Anode is Negative, Cathode is Positive", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7646", "front": "What is the function of the salt bridge in an electrochemical cell?", "back": "Maintain electrical neutrality (allow ion flow)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7647", "front": "What is the SI unit for the quantity of electric charge, equal to $\text{A} \cdot \text{s}$?", "back": "Coulomb ($\text{C}$)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7648", "front": "What is the magnitude of the charge of one mole of electrons (Faraday constant, $F$)?", "back": "$96,485 \text{ C/mol}$", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7649", "front": "What is the unit of electric potential energy per unit charge, often called voltage?", "back": "Volt ($\text{V}$) ($\text{J/C}$)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7650", "front": "What is the common term for the maximum useful work that can be done by a spontaneous process at constant temperature and pressure?", "back": "Gibbs Free Energy ($\Delta G$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7651", "front": "What is the relationship between $\Delta G$ and the standard cell potential ($E^\circ$)?", "back": "$\Delta G^\circ = -nF E^\circ$", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7652", "front": "If $E^\circ$ is positive, is $\Delta G^\circ$ positive or negative, and is the reaction spontaneous?", "back": "Negative, Spontaneous", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7653", "front": "What is the term for the amount of substance produced or consumed in an electrolytic cell, governed by the charge passed?", "back": "Faraday's Law of Electrolysis", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7654", "front": "What is the common term for the protective layer formed on the surface of some metals (e.g., Aluminum) that prevents further corrosion?", "back": "Passivation Layer (or Oxide Layer)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7655", "front": "What is the technique used to determine the concentration of a dissolved metal by oxidizing it at an electrode?", "back": "Voltammetry (or Stripping Voltammetry)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7656", "front": "What is the common name for the simple, saturated hydrocarbon with the formula $\text{CH}_4$?", "back": "Methane", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7657", "front": "What is the common name for the simple, saturated hydrocarbon with the formula $\text{C}_2\text{H}_6$?", "back": "Ethane", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7658", "front": "What is the common name for the simple, unsaturated hydrocarbon with the formula $\text{C}_2\text{H}_4$?", "back": "Ethene (Ethylene)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7659", "front": "What is the common name for the simple, unsaturated hydrocarbon with the formula $\text{C}_2\text{H}_2$?", "back": "Ethyne (Acetylene)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7660", "front": "What is the term for two or more compounds with the same molecular formula but different arrangements of atoms in space?", "back": "Stereoisomers", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7661", "front": "What type of stereoisomerism arises from restricted rotation around a double bond?", "back": "Geometric Isomerism (cis-trans or $E/Z$)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7662", "front": "What is the term for the process of joining two molecules together with the loss of a small molecule, such as water?", "back": "Condensation Reaction", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7663", "front": "What is the term for the process of breaking a molecule apart by the addition of a water molecule?", "back": "Hydrolysis Reaction", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7664", "front": "What is the name for the simplest aromatic ring compound ($\text{C}_6\text{H}_6$)?", "back": "Benzene", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7665", "front": "What type of reaction is characteristic of alkenes and alkynes (involving the breaking of $\pi$ bonds)?", "back": "Addition Reaction", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7666", "front": "What type of reaction is characteristic of alkanes and aromatic compounds (involving the replacement of an atom/group)?", "back": "Substitution Reaction", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7667", "front": "What is the term for the removal of atoms or groups from a molecule, often forming a double bond?", "back": "Elimination Reaction", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7668", "front": "What is the common name for the structural unit of a polymer?", "back": "Monomer", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7669", "front": "What is the term for a polymer consisting of only one type of monomer?", "back": "Homopolymer", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7670", "front": "What is the term for a polymer consisting of two or more different types of monomers?", "back": "Copolymer", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7671", "front": "What is the name for the structural units of $\text{DNA}$ and $\text{RNA}$?", "back": "Nucleotides", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7672", "front": "What is the name for the bond that links nucleotides together to form the backbone of $\text{DNA/RNA}$?", "back": "Phosphodiester Bond", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7673", "front": "What is the complementary base pair for Adenine ($\text{A}$) in $\text{DNA}$?", "back": "Thymine ($\text{T}$)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7674", "front": "What is the complementary base pair for Guanine ($\text{G}$) in $\text{DNA}$?", "back": "Cytosine ($\text{C}$)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7675", "front": "How many hydrogen bonds are formed between Adenine ($\text{A}$) and Thymine ($\text{T}$) in $\text{DNA}$?", "back": "Two (2)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7676", "front": "How many hydrogen bonds are formed between Guanine ($\text{G}$) and Cytosine ($\text{C}$) in $\text{DNA}$?", "back": "Three (3)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7677", "front": "What is the name for the process where a protein loses its native structure due to external stress (e.g., heat, $\text{pH}$)?", "back": "Denaturation", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7678", "front": "What is the term for a chemical species that changes its oxidation state during a reaction?", "back": "Redox Species (or Reactant)", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7679", "front": "In a redox reaction, which species is the one that is **reduced** (and causes oxidation)?", "back": "Oxidizing Agent", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7680", "front": "In a redox reaction, which species is the one that is **oxidized** (and causes reduction)?", "back": "Reducing Agent", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7681", "front": "What is the term for the process of balancing a redox reaction by separating it into two half-reactions (oxidation and reduction)?", "back": "Half-Reaction Method", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7682", "front": "What is the oxidation state of sulfur in the sulfate ion ($\text{SO}_4^{2-}$)?", "back": "$+6$", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7683", "front": "What is the oxidation state of manganese in the permanganate ion ($\text{MnO}_4^{-}$)?", "back": "$+7$", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7684", "front": "What is the term for a chemical species that exhibits both oxidizing and reducing properties (e.g., $\text{H}_2\text{O}_2$)?", "back": "Amphiprotic (or Disproportionating Agent)", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7685", "front": "What is the term for the process where a single substance is both oxidized and reduced simultaneously?", "back": "Disproportionation Reaction", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7686", "front": "What is the study of matter and radiation in outer space?", "back": "Astrochemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7687", "front": "What is the term for the chemistry that occurs on or within the Earth's atmosphere?", "back": "Atmospheric Chemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7688", "front": "What is the term for the chemistry of environmental systems, including soil and water?", "back": "Environmental Chemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7689", "front": "What is the term for the conversion of a metal from an elemental state to an ionic state by reaction with a nonmetal (e.g., rusting)?", "back": "Corrosion (Oxidation)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7690", "front": "What is the term for the technique of attaching a more easily oxidized metal to a structural metal to prevent corrosion?", "back": "Cathodic Protection (using a Sacrificial Anode)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7691", "front": "What is the most common metal used as a sacrificial anode for the protection of steel structures?", "back": "Magnesium ($\text{Mg}$), Zinc ($\text{Zn}$), or Aluminum ($\text{Al}$)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7692", "front": "What is the term for a solid solution where atoms of the solvent and solute are similar in size and occupy the same lattice positions?", "back": "Substitutional Alloy (e.g., Brass)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7693", "front": "What is the term for a solid solution where atoms of the solute are much smaller than the solvent and occupy spaces between the solvent atoms?", "back": "Interstitial Alloy (e.g., Steel)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7694", "front": "What is the name for the theory that explains metallic bonding through a lattice of positive ions immersed in a 'sea' of delocalized electrons?", "back": "Electron Sea Model (or Band Theory)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7695", "front": "What is the term for the narrow band of energy levels in a solid that is available for electrons to move into, enabling electrical conduction?", "back": "Conduction Band", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7696", "front": "What is the term for a material with a very small energy gap between its valence and conduction bands (e.g., silicon)?", "back": "Semiconductor", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7697", "front": "What is the term for the process of intentionally adding impurities to a semiconductor to control its electrical conductivity?", "back": "Doping", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7698", "front": "What is the common term for a solution that has a relatively small amount of solute dissolved in the solvent?", "back": "Dilute Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7699", "front": "What is the common term for a solution that has a large amount of solute dissolved in the solvent?", "back": "Concentrated Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7700", "front": "What is the term for the maximum amount of solute that can be dissolved in a given amount of solvent at a specific temperature?", "back": "Solubility", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7701", "front": "What is the name for the equation that relates the solubility of a gas to its partial pressure above the liquid?", "back": "Henry's Law", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7702", "front": "What is the general term for a property of a solution that depends only on the number of solute particles, not on their identity?", "back": "Colligative Property", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7703", "front": "What are the four common colligative properties?", "back": "Vapor Pressure Lowering, Boiling Point Elevation, Freezing Point Depression, and Osmotic Pressure", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7704", "front": "What is the name for the equation that relates the vapor pressure of a solution to the mole fraction of the solvent?", "back": "Raoult's Law", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7705", "front": "What is the name for the constant used to calculate boiling point elevation ($\Delta T_b$)?", "back": "Ebullioscopic Constant ($K_b$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7706", "front": "What is the name for the constant used to calculate freezing point depression ($\Delta T_f$)?", "back": "Cryoscopic Constant ($K_f$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7707", "front": "What is the van't Hoff factor ($i$)?", "back": "The number of ions a solute dissociates into in a solution (for electrolytes)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7708", "front": "What is the van't Hoff factor ($i$) for $\text{NaCl}$ in water?", "back": "Approximately $2$ (dissociates into $\text{Na}^+$ and $\text{Cl}^{-}$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7709", "front": "What is the van't Hoff factor ($i$) for glucose (a non-electrolyte)?", "back": "$1$", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7710", "front": "What is the term for a solution that follows Raoult's Law exactly?", "back": "Ideal Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7711", "front": "What is the term for a solution that does **not** follow Raoult's Law exactly?", "back": "Non-Ideal Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7712", "front": "What is the term for the process of using the $\text{K}_{sp}$ value to predict whether a precipitate will form?", "back": "Solubility Product Principle", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7713", "front": "What is the common term for a substance that can be oxidized or reduced in a redox reaction?", "back": "Redox Agent", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7714", "front": "What is the term for the removal of an electron from an atom or ion?", "back": "Oxidation", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7715", "front": "What is the term for the gain of an electron by an atom or ion?", "back": "Reduction", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7716", "front": "What is the mnemonic for remembering oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer?", "back": "$\text{OILRIG}$ (Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain)", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7717", "front": "What is the oxidation state of hydrogen in $\text{H}_2\text{O}$?", "back": "$+1$", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7718", "front": "What is the oxidation state of oxygen in $\text{H}_2\text{O}$?", "back": "$-2$", "subject": "Redox" },
    { "id": "7719", "front": "What is the term for a reaction where the atoms of one element replace the atoms of another element in a compound?", "back": "Single-Replacement Reaction", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7720", "front": "What is the term for a reaction where the cations of two ionic compounds swap places?", "back": "Double-Replacement Reaction (or Metathesis)", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7721", "front": "What is the term for a reaction where two or more substances combine to form a single, more complex substance?", "back": "Synthesis (or Combination) Reaction", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7722", "front": "What is the term for a reaction where a single compound is broken down into two or more simpler substances?", "back": "Decomposition Reaction", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7723", "front": "What is the common term for a substance that is present at the start of a chemical reaction?", "back": "Reactant", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7724", "front": "What is the common term for a substance that is formed during a chemical reaction?", "back": "Product", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7725", "front": "What is the term for the relationship between the quantities of reactants and products in a chemical reaction?", "back": "Stoichiometry", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7726", "front": "What is the term for the process of calculating the amount of product formed from a given amount of reactant?", "back": "Stoichiometric Calculation", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7727", "front": "What is the term for the amount of substance that contains $6.022 \times 10^{23}$ particles?", "back": "Mole ($\text{mol}$)", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7728", "front": "What is the value of Avogadro's number?", "back": "$6.022 \times 10^{23}$", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7729", "front": "What is the term for the mass in grams of one mole of a substance?", "back": "Molar Mass (or Molecular Weight)", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7730", "front": "What is the unit of Molar Mass?", "back": "$\text{g/mol}$", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7731", "front": "What is the term for the amount of energy released when one mole of gaseous atoms forms one mole of gaseous ions with a $-1$ charge?", "back": "First Electron Affinity", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7732", "front": "What is the term for the tendency of an atom to form a positive ion?", "back": "Metallic Character (or Low Ionization Energy)", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7733", "front": "What is the common term for the vertical columns on the periodic table?", "back": "Groups (or Families)", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7734", "front": "What is the common term for the horizontal rows on the periodic table?", "back": "Periods", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7735", "front": "What group of elements are known as the **Alkali Metals**?", "back": "Group 1", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7736", "front": "What group of elements are known as the **Alkaline Earth Metals**?", "back": "Group 2", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7737", "front": "What group of elements are known as the **Halogens**?", "back": "Group 17", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7738", "front": "What group of elements are known as the **Noble Gases**?", "back": "Group 18", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7739", "front": "What is the term for elements that exhibit properties of both metals and nonmetals?", "back": "Metalloids (or Semimetals)", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7740", "front": "What is the common name for the elements in the $d$-block of the periodic table?", "back": "Transition Metals", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7741", "front": "What is the common name for the elements in the $f$-block of the periodic table?", "back": "Inner Transition Metals (Lanthanides and Actinides)", "subject": "Periodic Trends" },
    { "id": "7742", "front": "What is the term for the energy required to break a chemical bond in a gaseous molecule?", "back": "Bond Energy (or Bond Enthalpy)", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7743", "front": "What is the term for a covalent bond where the electrons are shared equally between the atoms?", "back": "Nonpolar Covalent Bond", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7744", "front": "What is the term for a covalent bond where the electrons are shared unequally between the atoms?", "back": "Polar Covalent Bond", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7745", "front": "What type of bond forms between two atoms with a large difference in electronegativity ($> 1.7$)?", "back": "Ionic Bond", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7746", "front": "What is the term for a bond where both electrons in the shared pair are contributed by only one of the atoms?", "back": "Coordinate Covalent Bond (or Dative Bond)", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7747", "front": "What is the term for a molecule that has both an overall positive and an overall negative end?", "back": "Dipole (or Polar Molecule)", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7748", "front": "What is the common term for the average value of the bond lengths in a molecule exhibiting resonance?", "back": "Resonance Hybrid Structure", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7749", "front": "What is the VSEPR geometry of a central atom with two electron domains and zero lone pairs (e.g., $\text{BeCl}_2$)?", "back": "Linear", "subject": "Bonding & Geometry" },
    { "id": "7750", "front": "What is the VSEPR geometry of a central atom with three electron domains and zero lone pairs (e.g., $\text{BF}_3$)?", "back": "Trigonal Planar", "subject": "Bonding & Geometry" },
    { "id": "7751", "front": "What is the VSEPR geometry of a central atom with four electron domains and zero lone pairs (e.g., $\text{CH}_4$)?", "back": "Tetrahedral", "subject": "Bonding & Geometry" },
    { "id": "7752", "front": "What is the VSEPR geometry of a central atom with four domains and one lone pair (e.g., $\text{NH}_3$)?", "back": "Trigonal Pyramidal", "subject": "Bonding & Geometry" },
    { "id": "7753", "front": "What is the VSEPR geometry of a central atom with four domains and two lone pairs (e.g., $\text{H}_2\text{O}$)?", "back": "Bent (or V-shaped)", "subject": "Bonding & Geometry" },
    { "id": "7754", "front": "What is the hybridization of the central atom in a tetrahedral geometry?", "back": "$sp^3$", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7755", "front": "What is the hybridization of the central atom in a trigonal planar geometry?", "back": "$sp^2$", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7756", "front": "What is the hybridization of the central atom in a linear geometry with two sigma bonds?", "back": "$sp$", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7757", "front": "What type of intermolecular force occurs between a temporary dipole and an induced dipole?", "back": "London Dispersion Forces (LDF)", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7758", "front": "What type of intermolecular force occurs between two permanent dipoles?", "back": "Dipole-Dipole Forces", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7759", "front": "What is the name for the special, strong type of dipole-dipole force involving $\text{H}$ bonded to $\text{F, O}$, or $\text{N}$?", "back": "Hydrogen Bonding", "subject": "Bonding" },
    { "id": "7760", "front": "What type of solid is held together by LDF, Dipole-Dipole, and Hydrogen Bonds (e.g., ice, sugar)?", "back": "Molecular Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7761", "front": "What type of solid is held together by electrostatic attractions (e.g., $\text{NaCl}, \text{CaCO}_3$)?", "back": "Ionic Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7762", "front": "What type of solid consists of atoms held together by a network of covalent bonds (e.g., diamond, quartz)?", "back": "Covalent Network Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7763", "front": "What type of solid consists of atoms held together by a 'sea' of delocalized electrons (e.g., $\text{Cu}, \text{Fe}$)?", "back": "Metallic Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7764", "front": "Which type of solid generally has the highest melting point?", "back": "Covalent Network Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7765", "front": "Which type of solid generally has the lowest melting point?", "back": "Molecular Solid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7766", "front": "What is the term for a substance that can act as both an acid and a base (e.g., water)?", "back": "Amphoteric (or Amphiprotic)", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7767", "front": "According to the Brønsted-Lowry definition, what is an acid?", "back": "A proton ($\text{H}^+$) donor", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7768", "front": "According to the Brønsted-Lowry definition, what is a base?", "back": "A proton ($\text{H}^+$) acceptor", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7769", "front": "What is the relationship between an acid and the species formed when it loses a proton?", "back": "Conjugate Base", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7770", "front": "What is the relationship between a base and the species formed when it gains a proton?", "back": "Conjugate Acid", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7771", "front": "What does a large $\text{Ka}$ value indicate about an acid?", "back": "It is a Stronger Acid", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7772", "front": "What is the term for the common-ion effect in solubility equilibrium?", "back": "The solubility of a sparingly soluble salt decreases when a common ion is added.", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7773", "front": "What is the term for the point in a titration where $\text{pH} = \text{pKa}$ of the weak acid?", "back": "Half-Equivalence Point", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7774", "front": "What is the major species present in solution at the half-equivalence point of a weak acid titration?", "back": "$[\text{Weak Acid}] = [\text{Conjugate Base}]$ (Buffer)", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7775", "front": "What is the name for the ion ($\text{H}_3\text{O}^+$) that $\text{H}^+$ immediately forms when dissolved in water?", "back": "Hydronium Ion", "subject": "Acids and Bases" },
    { "id": "7776", "front": "What is the term for a process that occurs without continuous outside intervention ($\Delta G < 0$)?", "back": "Spontaneous Process", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7777", "front": "What is the term for a measure of the randomness or disorder of a system?", "back": "Entropy ($\text{S}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7778", "front": "What does the Second Law of Thermodynamics state about the total entropy of the universe?", "back": "It always increases for a spontaneous process ($\Delta S_{\text{universe}} > 0$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7779", "front": "What does the Third Law of Thermodynamics state about the entropy of a perfect crystal at absolute zero?", "back": "It is zero ($\text{S} = 0 \text{ at } 0 \text{ K}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7780", "front": "What is the term for the relationship that links $\Delta G$, $\Delta H$, and $\Delta S$?", "back": "Gibbs Free Energy Equation ($\Delta G = \Delta H - T\Delta S$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7781", "front": "If $\Delta H$ is negative and $\Delta S$ is positive, is the reaction spontaneous at all temperatures?", "back": "Yes (Exothermic and Increasing Disorder)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7782", "front": "If $\Delta H$ is positive and $\Delta S$ is negative, is the reaction spontaneous at any temperature?", "back": "No (Endothermic and Decreasing Disorder)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7783", "front": "What is the term for the point at which $\Delta G = 0$?", "back": "Equilibrium Point", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7784", "front": "What is the relationship between $\Delta G^\circ$ and the equilibrium constant ($\text{K}$)?", "back": "$\Delta G^\circ = -R\text{T} \ln(\text{K})$", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7785", "front": "What is the term for the minimum energy required for a chemical reaction to occur?", "back": "Activation Energy ($E_a$)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7786", "front": "What is the term for the unstable, high-energy arrangement of atoms at the peak of the energy profile diagram?", "back": "Transition State (or Activated Complex)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7787", "front": "What is the name for the equation that relates the rate constant ($k$) to the temperature and activation energy?", "back": "Arrhenius Equation", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7788", "front": "What is the term for a catalyst that is in the same phase as the reactants (e.g., acid in solution)?", "back": "Homogeneous Catalyst", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7789", "front": "What is the term for a catalyst that is in a different phase from the reactants (e.g., solid metal in gas phase)?", "back": "Heterogeneous Catalyst", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7790", "front": "What is the term for a series of elementary steps that, when added together, give the overall balanced equation?", "back": "Reaction Mechanism", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7791", "front": "What is the term for a species that is produced in one step of a mechanism and consumed in a subsequent step?", "back": "Reaction Intermediate", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7792", "front": "What is the common term for a solution where the solvent is water?", "back": "Aqueous Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7793", "front": "What is the concentration unit defined as moles of solute per liter of solution?", "back": "Molarity ($\text{M}$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7794", "front": "What is the concentration unit defined as moles of solute per kilogram of solvent?", "back": "Molality ($m$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7795", "front": "What is the concentration unit defined as moles of component per total moles of solution?", "back": "Mole Fraction ($\chi$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7796", "front": "What concentration unit is temperature-dependent?", "back": "Molarity ($\text{M}$) (since volume changes with temperature)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7797", "front": "What is the term for the minimum pressure required to prevent the flow of pure solvent into a solution across a semipermeable membrane?", "back": "Osmotic Pressure ($\pi$)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7798", "front": "What is the name for the process of separating components in a solution based on their different interactions with a stationary phase and a mobile phase?", "back": "Chromatography", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7799", "front": "What is the term for the ratio used in chromatography that describes how far a spot travels relative to the solvent front?", "back": "Retention Factor ($\text{R}_f$)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7800", "front": "What is the name for the separation technique used to separate components of a mixture based on boiling point differences?", "back": "Distillation (Fractional Distillation)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7801", "front": "What is the common name for the structural unit that makes up proteins?", "back": "Amino Acids", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7802", "front": "What is the name for the covalent bond that links amino acids together in a protein chain?", "back": "Peptide Bond (or Amide Bond)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7803", "front": "What is the general term for a long chain of amino acids?", "back": "Polypeptide", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7804", "front": "What is the term for the unique sequence of amino acids in a protein chain?", "back": "Primary Structure", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7805", "front": "What are the two common, repeating shapes (coiling and folding) formed by the polypeptide backbone (due to $\text{H}$-bonds)?", "back": "Alpha Helix ($\alpha$-helix) and Beta Pleated Sheet ($\beta$-sheet)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7806", "front": "What is the term for the three-dimensional folding of a single polypeptide chain?", "back": "Tertiary Structure", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7807", "front": "What is the term for the arrangement of multiple polypeptide subunits in a functional protein?", "back": "Quaternary Structure", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7808", "front": "What is the term for a biological catalyst that speeds up a reaction without being consumed?", "back": "Enzyme", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7809", "front": "What is the common term for the substance upon which an enzyme acts?", "back": "Substrate", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7810", "front": "What is the term for the specific region on an enzyme where the substrate binds?", "back": "Active Site", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7811", "front": "What is the common name for the simplest sugar ($\text{C}_6\text{H}_{12}\text{O}_6$)?", "back": "Glucose (or Fructose, Galactose)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7812", "front": "What is the name for the ether bond linking two sugar units?", "back": "Glycosidic Linkage (or Glycosidic Bond)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7813", "front": "What is the name for the bond between the sugar and the base in a nucleotide?", "back": "N-Glycosidic Bond", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7814", "front": "What is the term for the process of using the structure of a protein to predict its function?", "back": "Structural Biology (or Bioinformatics)", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7815", "front": "What is the term for the process of converting light energy into chemical energy by plants?", "back": "Photosynthesis", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7816", "front": "What is the term for the process of breaking down glucose to release energy ($\text{ATP}$)?", "back": "Cellular Respiration", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7817", "front": "What is the formula for the volume of a sphere in terms of its radius ($r$)?", "back": "$V = \frac{4}{3} \pi r^3$", "subject": "Math in Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7818", "front": "What is the definition of **precision** in measurement?", "back": "How close repeated measurements are to one another (reproducibility)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7819", "front": "What is the definition of **accuracy** in measurement?", "back": "How close a measurement is to the true or accepted value", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7820", "front": "When adding or subtracting measurements, which rule governs the number of significant figures in the result?", "back": "The result is limited by the measurement with the fewest decimal places.", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7821", "front": "When multiplying or dividing measurements, which rule governs the number of significant figures in the result?", "back": "The result is limited by the measurement with the fewest significant figures.", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7822", "front": "How many significant figures are in the measurement $\text{10.050 g}$?", "back": "Five (5)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7823", "front": "How many significant figures are in the measurement $\text{0.0025 \text{ L}}$?", "back": "Two (2)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7824", "front": "How many significant figures are in the measurement $\text{2500 \text{ m}}$ (assumed no decimal point)?", "back": "Two (2)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7825", "front": "How many significant figures are in the measurement $\text{2500. \text{ m}}$ (with decimal point)?", "back": "Four (4)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7826", "front": "What is the common term for the positive difference between the experimental and theoretical yields?", "back": "Positive Error (or Excess Yield)", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7827", "front": "What is the common term for the negative difference between the experimental and theoretical yields?", "back": "Negative Error (or Loss/Lower Yield)", "subject": "Stoichiometry" },
    { "id": "7828", "front": "What is the term for the standard conditions for temperature, pressure, and concentration used for half-cell potentials?", "back": "Standard Reduction Potential (usually $25^\circ\text{C}, 1 \text{ atm}, 1 \text{ M}$)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7829", "front": "What is the name for the equation used to calculate the cell potential ($E$) under non-standard conditions?", "back": "Nernst Equation", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7830", "front": "What is the common term for the device that converts chemical energy from a spontaneous redox reaction directly into electrical energy?", "back": "Galvanic Cell (or Voltaic Cell)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7831", "front": "What is the common term for the device that uses electrical energy to drive a non-spontaneous redox reaction?", "back": "Electrolytic Cell", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7832", "front": "In an electrolytic cell, which electrode is typically negative and which is positive?", "back": "Anode is Positive, Cathode is Negative", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7833", "front": "What is the term for the process of applying an electric current to decompose a substance (e.g., separating water into $\text{H}_2$ and $\text{O}_2$)?", "back": "Electrolysis", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7834", "front": "What is the name for the chemical process that causes iron to rust (hydrated iron(III) oxide)?", "back": "Corrosion (or Oxidation of Iron)", "subject": "Electrochemistry" },
    { "id": "7835", "front": "What is the term for a material that allows electricity to flow through it easily?", "back": "Conductor", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7836", "front": "What is the term for a material that resists the flow of electricity?", "back": "Insulator", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7837", "front": "What is the term for the spontaneous emission of radiation from an unstable atomic nucleus?", "back": "Radioactivity (or Radioactive Decay)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7838", "front": "What type of nuclear decay involves the emission of a helium nucleus ($\text{He}^{2+}$)?", "back": "Alpha Decay ($\alpha$)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7839", "front": "What type of nuclear decay involves the conversion of a neutron into a proton and the emission of an electron?", "back": "Beta Decay ($\beta^-$)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7840", "front": "What type of nuclear emission involves high-energy electromagnetic radiation (photons) with no mass or charge change?", "back": "Gamma Emission ($\gamma$)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7841", "front": "What is the term for the time required for half of the nuclei in a radioactive sample to decay?", "back": "Half-Life ($t_{1/2}$)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7842", "front": "What is the common term for the process of using carbon-14 decay to determine the age of organic materials?", "back": "Carbon Dating", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7843", "front": "What is the term for the splitting of a heavy atomic nucleus into two or more smaller nuclei?", "back": "Nuclear Fission", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7844", "front": "What is the term for the joining of two lighter atomic nuclei to form a heavier nucleus?", "back": "Nuclear Fusion", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7845", "front": "Which process, fission or fusion, powers the sun?", "back": "Nuclear Fusion", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7846", "front": "What is the term for the difference between the mass of a nucleus and the sum of the masses of its individual nucleons?", "back": "Mass Defect", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7847", "front": "What equation relates mass defect to nuclear binding energy?", "back": "Einstein's Mass-Energy Equivalence ($E=mc^2$)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7848", "front": "What is the term for the minimum amount of fissile material needed to sustain a nuclear chain reaction?", "back": "Critical Mass", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7849", "front": "What is the term for the controlled, continuous process of nuclear fission?", "back": "Nuclear Chain Reaction", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7850", "front": "What is the common term for an instrument used to detect and measure ionizing radiation?", "back": "Geiger Counter (or Scintillation Counter)", "subject": "Nuclear Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7851", "front": "What is the IUPAC name for the hydrocarbon with the formula $\text{C}_3\text{H}_8$?", "back": "Propane", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7852", "front": "What is the IUPAC name for the straight-chain alkane with six carbon atoms?", "back": "Hexane", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7853", "front": "What is the functional group present in an **alcohol**?", "back": "Hydroxyl group ($\text{-OH}$)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7854", "front": "What is the functional group present in an **aldehyde**?", "back": "Carbonyl group ($\text{C=O}$) at the end of a chain ($\text{-CHO}$)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7855", "front": "What is the functional group present in a **ketone**?", "back": "Carbonyl group ($\text{C=O}$) within a chain", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7856", "front": "What is the functional group present in a **carboxylic acid**?", "back": "Carboxyl group ($\text{-COOH}$)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7857", "front": "What is the name for the process of preparing soap by the hydrolysis of fats/oils with a strong base?", "back": "Saponification", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7858", "front": "What is the term for a molecule that contains both polar (hydrophilic) and nonpolar (hydrophobic) regions (e.g., soap)?", "back": "Amphiphilic (or Amphipathic)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7859", "front": "What is the name for the general structure of a fatty acid tail (a long chain of $\text{C}$ and $\text{H}$)?", "back": "Hydrocarbon Chain", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
    { "id": "7860", "front": "What is the term for a hydrocarbon that contains only single $\text{C}-\text{C}$ bonds?", "back": "Saturated Hydrocarbon (Alkane)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7861", "front": "What is the term for a hydrocarbon that contains at least one $\text{C}=\text{C}$ or $\text{C}\equiv\text{C}$ bond?", "back": "Unsaturated Hydrocarbon (Alkene or Alkyne)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7862", "front": "What is the term for the simplest repeating unit of a polymer structure?", "back": "Repeating Unit", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7863", "front": "What is the common name for the polymer formed from the monomer $\text{CH}_2=\text{CH}_2$?", "back": "Polyethylene (PE)", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7864", "front": "What type of polymerization involves the addition of monomers without the loss of any atoms?", "back": "Addition Polymerization", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7865", "front": "What type of polymerization involves the joining of monomers with the loss of a small molecule (usually water)?", "back": "Condensation Polymerization", "subject": "Polymers" },
    { "id": "7866", "front": "What is the common term for the substance that makes up the bulk of a solution?", "back": "Solvent", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7867", "front": "What is the common term for the substance present in a minor amount in a solution?", "back": "Solute", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7868", "front": "What is the name for the effect where the scattering of light makes the beam visible in a colloid or suspension?", "back": "Tyndall Effect", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7869", "front": "What is the common term for a solution where the solute particles are small (e.g., salt water)?", "back": "True Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7870", "front": "What is the common term for a homogeneous mixture where solute particles are larger than a true solution but still dispersed (e.g., milk)?", "back": "Colloid (or Colloidal Dispersion)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7871", "front": "What is the common term for a heterogeneous mixture where particles are large enough to settle out over time (e.g., muddy water)?", "back": "Suspension", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7872", "front": "What is the common term for a compound that conducts electricity when dissolved in water?", "back": "Electrolyte", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7873", "front": "What is the common term for a compound that does **not** conduct electricity when dissolved in water?", "back": "Non-Electrolyte", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7874", "front": "What is the term for the standard heat change associated with the dissolution of one mole of a solute in a solvent?", "back": "Enthalpy of Solution ($\Delta H_{soln}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7875", "front": "What is the term for the energy change associated with breaking the solvent-solvent intermolecular forces?", "back": "Endothermic ($\Delta H_1 > 0$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7876", "front": "What is the term for the energy change associated with forming the solute-solvent intermolecular forces?", "back": "Exothermic ($\Delta H_3 < 0$) (Solvation/Hydration)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7877", "front": "What is the name for the equation that relates the pressure and volume of a fixed amount of gas at constant temperature?", "back": "Boyle's Law ($P_1V_1 = P_2V_2$)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7878", "front": "What is the name for the equation that relates the volume and temperature of a fixed amount of gas at constant pressure?", "back": "Charles's Law ($V_1/T_1 = V_2/T_2$)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7879", "front": "What is the name for the equation that relates the pressure and temperature of a fixed amount of gas at constant volume?", "back": "Gay-Lussac's Law ($P_1/T_1 = P_2/T_2$)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7880", "front": "What is the name for the temperature scale where $0$ is the absolute zero of temperature (used in gas laws)?", "back": "Kelvin ($\text{K}$)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7881", "front": "What is the conversion from Celsius ($\text{C}$) to Kelvin ($\text{K}$)?", "back": "$\text{K} = ^\circ\text{C} + 273.15$", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7882", "front": "What is the general term for the measure of the resistance of a liquid to flow?", "back": "Viscosity", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7883", "front": "What is the general term for the energy required to increase the surface area of a liquid by a unit amount?", "back": "Surface Tension", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7884", "front": "What is the term for the attractive forces between two molecules of the **same** type (e.g., water-water)?", "back": "Cohesive Forces", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7885", "front": "What is the term for the attractive forces between two molecules of **different** types (e.g., water-glass)?", "back": "Adhesive Forces", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7886", "front": "What type of intermolecular force causes water to form a concave meniscus in a glass cylinder?", "back": "Adhesive forces are greater than cohesive forces", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7887", "front": "What is the name for the upward movement of a liquid through a narrow tube against the force of gravity?", "back": "Capillary Action", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7888", "front": "What is the term for the temperature at which the vapor pressure of a liquid equals the external atmospheric pressure?", "back": "Boiling Point", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7889", "front": "What is the term for a liquid with a high vapor pressure and low boiling point?", "back": "Volatile Liquid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7890", "front": "What is the term for a liquid with a low vapor pressure and high boiling point?", "back": "Non-Volatile Liquid", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7891", "front": "What is the name for the process of using chromatography to separate gases based on volatility?", "back": "Gas Chromatography ($\text{GC}$)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7892", "front": "What is the name for the process of using chromatography to separate liquid mixtures based on polarity, often on a column?", "back": "Column Chromatography (or Liquid Chromatography, $\text{LC}$)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7893", "front": "What is the name for the separation technique used to purify solids by dissolving them and letting them slowly reform a crystal structure?", "back": "Recrystallization", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7894", "front": "What is the common term for the device used to spin samples at high speed to separate components based on density?", "back": "Centrifuge", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7895", "front": "What is the common term for the solid substance that forms and separates from a liquid solution?", "back": "Precipitate", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7896", "front": "What type of chemical reaction produces a precipitate?", "back": "Precipitation Reaction (or Double-Replacement)", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7897", "front": "What is the common term for the ions in a solution that do not participate in the net ionic reaction?", "back": "Spectator Ions", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7898", "front": "What is the chemical equation that shows only the species that undergo a chemical change?", "back": "Net Ionic Equation", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7899", "front": "What is the term for a reaction that involves the transfer of an $\text{H}^+$ ion?", "back": "Acid-Base Reaction", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7900", "front": "What is the term for a reaction that involves the transfer of electrons?", "back": "Redox Reaction (Reduction-Oxidation)", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7901", "front": "What is the common term for the reaction of a substance with oxygen, usually producing heat and light?", "back": "Combustion Reaction", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7902", "front": "What are the common products of the complete combustion of a hydrocarbon?", "back": "Carbon Dioxide ($\text{CO}_2$) and Water ($\text{H}_2\text{O}$)", "subject": "Reactions" },
    { "id": "7903", "front": "What is the name for the theory that states that a reaction occurs when molecules collide with sufficient energy and correct orientation?", "back": "Collision Theory", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7904", "front": "What is the term for the measure of the minimum energy required for a collision to be effective?", "back": "Activation Energy ($E_a$)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7905", "front": "How does increasing the temperature affect the rate of most chemical reactions?", "back": "Increases the rate (increases collision frequency and energy)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7906", "front": "How does increasing the concentration of reactants affect the rate of most chemical reactions?", "back": "Increases the rate (increases collision frequency)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7907", "front": "What is the term for the measure of the rate of a reaction, usually in $\text{M}/\text{s}$?", "back": "Reaction Rate", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7908", "front": "What is the name for the constant that relates the rate of a reaction to the concentration of reactants?", "back": "Rate Constant ($k$)", "subject": "Kinetics" },
    { "id": "7909", "front": "What is the common term for the energy required to break all the bonds in one mole of a gaseous molecule into its constituent atoms?", "back": "Atomization Enthalpy", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7910", "front": "What is the term for the enthalpy change associated with the complete combustion of a substance in its standard state?", "back": "Standard Enthalpy of Combustion ($\Delta H_c^\circ$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7911", "front": "What is the term for the heat released or absorbed when an ionic compound dissolves in water?", "back": "Lattice Energy and Enthalpy of Hydration (sum is $\Delta H_{soln}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7912", "front": "What is the term for the energy required to break an ionic solid into its constituent gaseous ions?", "back": "Lattice Energy ($\Delta H_{lattice}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7913", "front": "What is the term for the energy change when gaseous ions are surrounded by water molecules?", "back": "Enthalpy of Hydration ($\Delta H_{hyd}$)", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7914", "front": "What is the name for the theoretical cycle used to calculate the lattice energy of an ionic compound?", "back": "Born-Haber Cycle", "subject": "Thermodynamics" },
    { "id": "7915", "front": "What is the term for a gas that obeys the ideal gas law under all conditions?", "back": "Ideal Gas", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7916", "front": "What is the term for a gas that deviates from the ideal gas law, especially at high pressure and low temperature?", "back": "Real Gas", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7917", "front": "According to the Kinetic Molecular Theory, what is the volume of the gas particles themselves compared to the volume of the container?", "back": "Negligible (Zero)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7918", "front": "According to the Kinetic Molecular Theory, what is the nature of the forces between gas particles?", "back": "Negligible (No attractive or repulsive forces)", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7919", "front": "What is the term for the gradual mixing of molecules of one gas with molecules of another gas due to random motion?", "back": "Diffusion", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7920", "front": "What is the term for the process by which gas molecules escape through a small hole in a container?", "back": "Effusion", "subject": "Gases" },
    { "id": "7921", "front": "What element is denoted by the symbol $\text{K}$?", "back": "Potassium", "subject": "Periodic Table" },
    { "id": "7922", "front": "What element is denoted by the symbol $\text{Ag}$?", "back": "Silver", "subject": "Periodic Table" },
    { "id": "7923", "front": "What element is denoted by the symbol $\text{Sn}$?", "back": "Tin", "subject": "Periodic Table" },
    { "id": "7924", "front": "What element is denoted by the symbol $\text{Pb}$?", "back": "Lead", "subject": "Periodic Table" },
    { "id": "7925", "front": "What is the common term for the temperature at which a pure solid turns into a liquid?", "back": "Melting Point (or Freezing Point)", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7926", "front": "What is the common term for the temperature at which a liquid turns into a gas (at $1 \text{ atm}$)?", "back": "Normal Boiling Point", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7927", "front": "What is the name for the plot of $\ln(\text{P}_{\text{vap}})$ versus $1/\text{T}$ for a liquid?", "back": "Clausius-Clapeyron Plot", "subject": "States of Matter" },
    { "id": "7928", "front": "What is the term for the process of a solid structure breaking apart and becoming dissolved in a solvent?", "back": "Dissolution (or Solvation/Hydration)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7929", "front": "What is the term for a solution that contains the maximum amount of dissolved solute at a given temperature?", "back": "Saturated Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7930", "front": "What is the term for a solution that contains less than the maximum amount of dissolved solute?", "back": "Unsaturated Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7931", "front": "What is the term for a solution that contains more than the maximum amount of dissolved solute, often unstable?", "back": "Supersaturated Solution", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7932", "front": "What is the term for the relationship that states 'like dissolves like'?", "back": "Solubility Principle (Polar dissolves Polar, Nonpolar dissolves Nonpolar)", "subject": "Solutions" },
    { "id": "7933", "front": "What is the term for the process of separating a liquid from a solid by carefully pouring off the liquid?", "back": "Decantation", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7934", "front": "What is the term for the process of separating a solid from a liquid by passing the mixture through a porous medium?", "back": "Filtration", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7935", "front": "What is the name for the standard laboratory vessel used to prepare solutions of known, precise concentrations?", "back": "Volumetric Flask", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7936", "front": "What is the name for the laboratory technique used to accurately dispense and measure variable volumes of liquid during a titration?", "back": "Burette (or Buret)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7937", "front": "What is the term for the substance with the precisely known concentration used as the reference in a titration?", "back": "Titrant (or Standard Solution)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7938", "front": "What is the term for the substance whose concentration is unknown and is being analyzed in a titration?", "back": "Analyte", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7939", "front": "What is the common term for a chemical species that changes its color in response to a specific chemical change (e.g., $\text{pH}$)?", "back": "Indicator", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7940", "front": "What is the term for the condition when the rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the reverse reaction?", "back": "Chemical Equilibrium (Dynamic Equilibrium)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7941", "front": "What is the name for the ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations at equilibrium?", "back": "Equilibrium Constant ($\text{K}$)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7942", "front": "What is the name for the principle that states that a system at equilibrium will shift to relieve stress?", "back": "Le Chatelier's Principle", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7943", "front": "How does adding an inert gas to a reaction at constant volume affect the equilibrium?", "back": "No effect", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7944", "front": "How does adding a catalyst affect the position of the equilibrium?", "back": "No effect (It speeds up both forward and reverse rates equally)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7945", "front": "In an exothermic reaction, how does increasing the temperature affect the value of the equilibrium constant ($\text{K}$)?", "back": "Decreases $\text{K}$ (favors reactants)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7946", "front": "In an endothermic reaction, how does increasing the temperature affect the value of the equilibrium constant ($\text{K}$)?", "back": "Increases $\text{K}$ (favors products)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7947", "front": "What is the term for the condition where the concentration of products is greater than the concentration of reactants at equilibrium ($\text{K} > 1$)?", "back": "Product-Favored (Equilibrium lies to the right)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7948", "front": "What is the term for the condition where the concentration of reactants is greater than the concentration of products at equilibrium ($\text{K} < 1$)?", "back": "Reactant-Favored (Equilibrium lies to the left)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7949", "front": "What is the term for the constant that governs the solubility of a sparingly soluble salt?", "back": "Solubility Product Constant ($\text{K}_{sp}$)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7950", "front": "What is the term for a solution where the $\text{Q}$ (reaction quotient) is equal to $\text{K}_{sp}$?", "back": "Saturated Solution (at equilibrium)", "subject": "Equilibrium" },
    { "id": "7951", "front": "What is the common term for a compound where the cation is a metal ion bonded to a neutral molecule or anion (a complex ion)?", "back": "Coordination Compound (or Complex)", "subject": "Inorganic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7952", "front": "What is the name for the neutral molecule or ion that acts as an electron pair donor to the central metal ion?", "back": "Ligand", "subject": "Inorganic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7953", "front": "What is the common term for the number of atoms or ions immediately surrounding a central atom in a complex or crystal?", "back": "Coordination Number", "subject": "Inorganic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7954", "front": "What is the name for the theory used to explain the magnetic properties and colors of transition metal complexes?", "back": "Crystal Field Theory (or Ligand Field Theory)", "subject": "Inorganic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7955", "front": "What is the term for the separation of $d$-orbital energies in a transition metal complex?", "back": "Crystal Field Splitting ($\Delta$)", "subject": "Inorganic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7956", "front": "What determines the color of a transition metal complex?", "back": "The energy difference ($\Delta$) between the split $d$-orbitals, which absorbs light of a specific wavelength.", "subject": "Inorganic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7957", "front": "What is the common term for the color of light that is not absorbed by a substance?", "back": "Complementary Color (Transmitted Color)", "subject": "Inorganic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7958", "front": "What is the most abundant element in the universe?", "back": "Hydrogen ($\text{H}$)", "subject": "Periodic Table" },
    { "id": "7959", "front": "What is the most abundant element in the Earth's crust?", "back": "Oxygen ($\text{O}$)", "subject": "Periodic Table" },
    { "id": "7960", "front": "What is the most abundant metal in the Earth's crust?", "back": "Aluminum ($\text{Al}$)", "subject": "Periodic Table" },
    { "id": "7961", "front": "What is the name for the process of generating energy by burning wood, coal, or oil?", "back": "Combustion (or Fossil Fuel Combustion)", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7962", "front": "What is the major gaseous product responsible for acid rain?", "back": "Sulfur Dioxide ($\text{SO}_2$) or Nitrogen Oxides ($\text{NO}_x$)", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7963", "front": "What is the major gaseous product responsible for global warming?", "back": "Carbon Dioxide ($\text{CO}_2$)", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7964", "front": "What is the name for the atmospheric layer that protects the Earth from harmful ultraviolet ($\text{UV}$) radiation?", "back": "Ozone Layer ($\text{O}_3$)", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7965", "front": "What class of synthetic compounds was primarily responsible for the depletion of the ozone layer?", "back": "Chlorofluorocarbons ($\text{CFCs}$)", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7966", "front": "What is the term for the contamination of water bodies (lakes, rivers, oceans) with chemical, physical, or biological material?", "back": "Water Pollution", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7967", "front": "What is the common term for the process of treating sewage to remove contaminants before discharge?", "back": "Wastewater Treatment (or Sewage Treatment)", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7968", "front": "What is the term for the increase in concentration of a substance in an organism or a trophic level?", "back": "Bioaccumulation (or Biomagnification)", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7969", "front": "What is the common term for the chemical process that uses sunlight to degrade pollutants?", "back": "Photodegradation", "subject": "Environmental Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7970", "front": "What is the term for the branch of chemistry focused on designing products and processes that minimize the use and generation of hazardous substances?", "back": "Green Chemistry", "subject": "General" },
    { "id": "7971", "front": "What is the general name for a carbon atom that is bonded to four different groups?", "back": "Chiral Center (or Stereocenter)", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7972", "front": "What is the term for the maximum possible rotational speed in a centrifuge, measured in revolutions per minute ($\text{rpm}$)?", "back": "Rotational Speed (or Centrifugal Force)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7973", "front": "What is the common term for the separation of a mixture by dissolving the components in a solvent and then using a separating funnel?", "back": "Solvent Extraction (or Liquid-Liquid Extraction)", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7974", "front": "What is the common term for the difference between the melting point of a pure substance and the melting point of an impure sample?", "back": "Melting Point Depression", "subject": "Analytical Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7975", "front": "What is the name for the property of a substance to rotate the plane of polarized light?", "back": "Optical Activity", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },

    { "id": "7977", "front": "What is the common term for a molecule that contains an equal number of $\text{D}$ and $\text{L}$ stereoisomers (a racemic mixture)?", "back": "Racemate", "subject": "Organic Chemistry" },
    { "id": "7978", "front": "What is the chemical name for ordinary table sugar (a disaccharide)?", "back": "Sucrose", "subject": "Biochemistry" },

    { "id": "7986", "front": "What is the common term for fats and oils (biological molecules)?", "back": "Lipids", "subject": "Biochemistry" },

    { "id": "7990", "front": "What is the name for the major component of cell membranes, having a hydrophilic head and two hydrophobic tails?", "back": "Phospholipid", "subject": "Biochemistry" },
